title: Your Favourite Fake Garamond?
content:
¶ Among the series of fake _Garamond_ based on Jean Jannon roman (aka _Caractère de l'université_, designated by the Cardinal de Richelieu), which one do you consider the best?

• _Garamond 3_ (1917) by Morris Fuller Benton  
• _Lanston Garamont_ (1921) by Frederic Goudy  
• _Monotype Garamond_ (1922)\*  
• _Peignot Garamond_ (1926) by Georges Peignot  
• _Simoncini Garamond_ (1961) by Francesco Simoncini  
• _ITC Garamond_ (1976) by Tony Stan

**Footnotes**  
Back in the previous century, the French publishing house [**Gallimard**](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417052915/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gallimard) bought a license of _Monotype Garamond_ and rename it _Garamond du Roi_ for a particular collection of book called [**La Bibliothèque de la Pléiade**](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417052915/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biblioth%C3%A8que_de_la_Pl%C3%A9iade).
author: Fournier

comments.content: I think Typoart Garamond (1955) by Herbert Thannhaeuser for Typoart (looks like an improved version of Monotype Garamond) and Garamont by Lettergieterij Amsterdam (a copy of the design by Morris Fuller Benton for ATF) should also be on a list of _faux_ Garamonds.
What do you think of [_Garamond Ludlow_](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417052915/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/redrooster/garamond-ludlow-rr/) (1929) by Robert Hunter Middleton?

Looks like a _faux Garamond_ too. At least at first sight. May be nice for display, unusable for text because it is far too thin. Elegant Garamond (Bistream. now Monotype) seems to be cloned from Ludlow Garamond.

**Let’s also do a list of _True_ Garamonds:**

Stempel Garamond (Stempel, 1925)  
_clones of Stempel Garamond:_  
Original Garamond (Bitstream)  
CG Garamond (Compugraphic, Agfa Compugraphic, now Monotype)

Sabon (Jan Tschichold, Stempel/Linotype/Monotype 1967)  
_clones of Sabon:_  
Sabon (Ascender, now Monotype)  
Classical Garamond (Bitstream, now Monotype)

Berthold Garamond (Günter Gerhard Lange, Berthold 1972)  
_clones of Berthold Garamond:_  
URW Garamond (URW)

Adobe Garamond (Robert Slimbach, Adobe, 1989)

Sabon Next (Jean François Porchez, Linotype, 2002)

Garamond Premier (Robert Slimbach, Adobe, 2005)

what else?
Albert: an old Bitstream catalogue equates Elegant Garamond with Granjon (Linotype), which I think is usually counted as a true Garamond, despite its name.

The Ludlow Garamond was 'revised & digitised' by Jill pichotta for Font Bureau

[http://www.fontbureau.com/fonts/serif/GaramondFB/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417052915/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/serif/GaramondFB/ "http://www.fontbureau.com/fonts/serif/GaramondFB/")

¶ The Ludlow version displays too much contrast so it can't be French Renaissance.

¶ Read the description of the updated Ludlow Garamond:

> Condé Nast commissioned the FB version of this popular oldstyle for Traveler magazine. Douglas Crawford McMurtrie, type historian, and type designer Robert Hunter Middleton collaborated at Ludlow in 1929 to design a light oldstyle roman and italic, then released them light-heartedly under the name of “Garamond”. Jill Pichotta revised and digitized them both, adding additional weights with italics to the series; FB 1992–2000.
So if you have one in hand, how do you tell if it is 'fake' or 'true'? If you don't have a list? If it isn't on a list?
Well, compare it to the ones that _are_ on the list. That would yield more accurate results than trying to put the distinction into words.
¶ Any thoughts on the typeface [Laurentian](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417052915/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/laurentian/) based on Garamond.

Looking it up, it apparently was based partly on Garamond and (to a lesser extent) partly on Caslon; it was a custom typeface created for the Canadian publication _Maclean's_ magazine. (Maclean's is Canada's major weekly news magazine, competing against TIME and Newsweek.)

Looking at the specimen on MyFonts, it didn't seem to have the distinctive "Garamond" feel I associate with the Jannon-based "fake" Garamonds, however, I wouldn't say that this necessarily brings it closer to the "real" Garamonds; it could, but I don't feel qualified to judge that.

> What about George Abrams’s Augereau?

¶ Abrams payed a tribute to the Garamond. Nice typeface and not far away from Slimbach.

> • Peignot Garamond (1926) by Georges Peignot

Is this what you mean?

![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417052915im_/http:/ic.pics.livejournal.com/m_zhukov/967599/45474/45474_600.gif)

Please notice the _Le_ in the name of the typeface, and the terminal _t_, not _d_ (that’s how Georges and Jacques Peignot spelled it), and the dates, 1914–23. The source: Charles Peignot. « Les Peignot : Georges, Charles ». _Communication & langages_, Volume 59, Issue 59. Paris : Armand Colin, 1984, p. 78.

> Please notice the Le in the name of the typeface, and the terminal t, not d (that’s how Georges and Jacques Peignot spelled it), and the dates, 1914–23. The source: Charles Peignot. « Les Peignot : Georges, Charles ». Communication & langages, Volume 59, Issue 59. Paris : Armand Colin, 1984, p. 78.

¶ It's the old controversy between the Latin nickname and the real name: Garamondus (Garamond) versus Garamont. Goudy also called his version Garamont.

¶ After using the name of Garamont's teacher, Augereau, any thoughts on the very rare hot metal _Linotype Estienne_ by George William Jones?

¶ I wonder why there are no _Le Bé_ or _Haultin_ typefaces?

¶ How would you define and classify the Garamond-oriented typefaces?
